speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next today in Case 13-1339, Spokeo v. Robins. Mr. Pincus.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Why is it you think --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Let's say I agree with you that there needs to be a concrete injury; that Congress Alderson Reporting Company needs to have recognized something that looks like a concrete injury. But why isn't that exactly what Congress did here? So let me just frame it in a hypothetical. Suppose that there's just a statute -- it's a little bit of a simpler statute, and you can argue with me or tell me why it might or might not be different, but I just want to understand your position. Suppose that there is a statute that just says that one of these credit reporting agencies shall not disseminate inaccurate information about people, or shall -- shall not do it willfully or negligently or what have you, but shall not disseminate inaccurate information about people. And then there's a cause of action that says if they disseminate inaccurate information in a credit report about you, you can sue. All right? Is that enough of a concrete injury for you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Okay. But let me focus on Alderson Reporting Company what seems to be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: --  the gravamen of the claim. And why isn't the dissemination of false information about you in a credit report, why isn't that --  why isn't it --  it perfectly sufficient if Congress says that's a concrete injury?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I'm sorry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You said that there were reasons why that was not a concrete injury --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: --  the dissemination of Alderson Reporting Company false information about a particular person. Why? Because to me, I'll just say, seems like a concrete injury to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You know? If -- I mean, if somebody did it to me I'd feel harmed. And I think that if you went out on the street and you did a survey, most people would feel harmed. Most people would feel as though they had some interest that had been invaded. And Congress recognized that, thought it was a significant problem, passed a statute to deal with that problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: That's quite right. It's not -- it's not completely in the common law tradition. But we've said many times that Congress gets to look beyond the common law tradition and gets to identify real world problems out there in the world, harming people in real-world ways. And that, it seems, is what Congress did here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can -- can you explain, then, the common law versus the legislature? So if we have some historic practice where damages are awarded to someone who has no out-of-pocket loss, if the common law says so it's okay but if Congress says so it's not? That's very strange.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry. You're saying -- contrary to one citation, you're actually -- Ashby v. White -- that it isn't a right that Congress Alderson Reporting Company has given you? I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I mean, most of the common law rights, like property rights, are -- are given to you by statute. They're not given to you by the common law. Most people are coming in to sue on the basis of a statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So if I have a dozen or more cases that didn't involve property rights, where we Alderson Reporting Company didn't require economic harm, those would mean nothing to you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Those legal rights, we just decided through the centuries, all those cases wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, what's the answer, then, to Justice Kagan's question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You said it could be psychic harm, there could be economic harm, there could be all different kinds of harm. And that being so, why isn't what she said right, that one kind of harm could be the harm suffered when somebody tells a lie about you, or gives false information? What's different?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: These are not --  these -- these are not unimportant details. This is a --  they basically got everything wrong about him. You know, they got his marital status wrong, they got his income wrong, they got his education wrong. They basically portrayed a different person than --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Here's the thing, Mr. Pincus. It seems to me that the -- the one thing that we have to say Congress is better at than we are is identifying concrete harms. I mean, it's perfectly fine, and I agree with very large portions of your brief when you say they have to have identified a concrete harm. It's like, fine, yes, they do. But now the question is, did they identify one? And it seems pretty clear what they wanted to do here; that this statute is entirely about preventing the dissemination of inaccurate information in credit reports which they seem to think is both something that harms the individual personally and also harms larger systemic issues. And then they gave the cause of action to the people it harmed personally. And I guess -- I mean, don't we owe them a little bit of respect that they've actually identified a real-world harm that it -- that's out there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, how much more do you think the plaintiff in this case would have to allege or prove in order to show injury in fact?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But that's a really hard thing to do, Mr. Pincus.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: People get these reports, Alderson Reporting Company and you don't know what they're doing with these reports. They might have not given you a job for that reason, or they might have not given you a job for some other reason. They might have not given you credit for that reason, or they might have not given you credit for some other reason. I mean, it's actually the quintessential kind of injury that you will never be able to detect and surely not to prove.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I suppose -- I suppose the argument underlying some of the questions you've been asked assumes this: If neighbors are making false comments, talking about someone, this is not actionable enough unless it's defamation. On the Internet with -- in this cyber age that we have where all this information is out, there's -- there's -- has to be some real injury. Is it different because this is a credit agency that is regulated? Alderson Reporting Company Does a credit agency have less latitude when it is defending on the ground of no concrete injury than other entities?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But does the statute apply just to crediting? That's what --  that's what I was asking.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's not disputed in this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It may have been disputed Alderson Reporting Company at an earlier stage, but now it's accepted that the defendant is a credit reporting agency.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We must assume that that's true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Isn't that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Isn't that, though, a question of the application of the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It doesn't invalidate Alderson Reporting Company the injury here because this is the quintessential violation of the statute. He's saying they don't have reasonable procedures to check their accuracy. We know from the purpose section of the statute that that's what Congress wanted, reasonable procedures. He's going to have to prove that. Number two, he says, the information about me is false. I'm going to assume, for purposes of this argument, because we have to, that --  and so does the court below with respect to standing --  that much of that information is inaccurate. I will tell you that I know plenty of single people who look at whether someone who's proposed to date is married or not. So if you're not married and there's a report out there saying you are, that's a potential injury. Now, I know the court below said it was speculative, but that's what Congress was worried about: both creditworthiness, and --  and your stature as a person, your privacy, your sense of self; that I can identify myself with some --  others can identify me with some accuracy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So I guess my question is, we've now taken a word, "concreteness," that the Court in recent years has applied to injuries by citizens and when they can bring actions or not. A generalized grievance, we said, of a taxpayer is not concrete enough. We've taken this doctrine, and you're trying to superimpose the word "concrete" into legally-created rights. But for -- for two decades -- on, I mean, two centuries, we've always said in our case law that injury in fact is the breach of a legally-recognized right. Where do we have a right? I think that's Justice Kagan's question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It's a requirement.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why don't you answer Justice Sotomayor's question first?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I agree with you entirely on that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Congress does it by doing it, you know? Congress doesn't announce exactly --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- here we are, we're just going beyond the common law. It just does it. And -- and it does it -- and it did it here. It said, you know, what are we concerned about? We're concerned about following the kinds of procedures that will make sure that there are accurate credit reports. And then Congress told you exactly why in the purposes section of the statute. And my gosh, it's all over the legislative history. The most serious problem in the credit reporting industry, Congress says, is the problem of inaccurate and misleading information.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And -- and so Congress has clearly done that here. And I guess I -- if you want to just explain to me why it is that Congress can't do -- I think we've said that Congress can do that, can go beyond the common Alderson Reporting Company law, and certainly can go beyond anything that we've ever said is a concrete harm as long as they've identified a concrete harm.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Of course, harms can arise in the world, and can be identified in the world even though they haven't arisen before, or been identified before.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: If you're saying that, I agree with you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Pincus, I would have thought that your answer to Justice Kagan would have been Congress did not identify, as the harm for which it allowed suit to be brought, misinformation. It did not. It identified as the harm the failure to follow the -- the procedures that it imposed upon credit reporting agencies. It said nothing about people who -- who have been hurt by misinformation being able to sue. It said anybody can sue who's been reported on if the agency failed to use the procedures. So in fact, Congress has not identified misinformation as a suable harm. That's not what this statute does.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't that your answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But why did Congress do that, Mr. Pincus? Congress did that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- Congress did that as a safe harbor. We are not -- it's a kind of industry-friendly act that Congress did. It said we're not going to punish any old inaccuracy. We're giving you a safe harbor. If -- as long as you followed a certain set of procedures, don't worry about it. But did that procedural requirement -- this is -- this is exactly what Lujan says, "It's a procedural requirement, the disregard of which could impair a concrete interest of the plaintiff." And we distinguished that from procedural requirements in vacuo.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And that's what this is. It's a procedural requirement, the disregard of which can impair your interest in being represented accurately in credit reports.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. That -- that would lead to the conclusion that anybody can sue --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- not just somebody who -- whose information was -- was wrong. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: "Any person who willfully fails to comply with any requirement imposed upon this subjecter with respect to any consumer is liable to that consumer." So it's not the whole world; it's the consumer that you dealt with --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- or that the agency -- that the agency dealt with.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, but, Mr. Pincus, the gravamen of this claim, as I said, and as more importantly, as --  as the --  the Respondent has said, is in 1681(e), which does talk about accuracy. And it makes it clear that the procedures are linked to accuracy. And I totally take your point that, well, how about the person who there's --  there's been no inaccuracy. Well, that person does not have standing. That person cannot come in and say that he's suffered a concrete injury. But the person who has been inaccurately represented can come in and say he's suffered exactly the concrete injury that this statute is designed to protect against.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are you --  are you saying --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Justice Kennedy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are you saying in this case that Congress could have drafted a statute that Alderson Reporting Company would allow this individual to bring suit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do all of them go to accuracy, or --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- do some of them go to privacy and other matters?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that would be a violation, right, if -- if you didn't provide that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and presumably anybody, if -- if you believe Respondent, anybody who -- whose information is not accurate can sue to get the statutory damages for failure to provide an number.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, I -- when we normally have a standing inquiry, you -- there can be some people who have standing under a particular statute and some who don't. Is -- is your position simply that you have to look at whether the plaintiffs have been injured in fact, and that some plaintiffs will be able to proceed if they can make that showing and others may not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, was this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: By the particular violation? Injured in fact by the particular --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not by failure to have an number, you're saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No. But would this man be able? I mean, this is very much in line with the Chief Justice's. Would he be able to sue based on the fact that there was inaccurate information about him? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Pincus --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I guess --  I guess what I -- that's okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Before you sit down, the --  the brief suggests that the real danger of allowing this kind of action is that it --  it will be brought on behalf of a class, and you could get millions of plaintiffs and billions of dollars. If we should hold that Congress can give consumers a right to redress for false credit reporting, if we held that, would you have grounds to oppose certification of a class.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Consovoy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- your -- your number two -- I mean, we can -- it sounds to me quite circular. You say -- you say he -- he has a personal stake because he has a -- because Congress said he has a personal stake. Alderson Reporting Company Is -- do I understand your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All Congress has to do is provide for damages, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but that is a harm. It is a harm. And you said it's a harm because he -- he can't get the money that he was provided. But that's circular. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What about a law that says you get a -- $10,000 statutory damages if a company publishes inaccurate information about you? You want -- you have an unlisted phone number. You don't want people calling you. The company publishes your phone number, but it's wrong. That is inaccurate information about you, but you have no injury whatever. Can that person bring an action for that statutory damage?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But -- but can you Alderson Reporting Company have -- do you have standing? Do you have injury in fact when you don't want people calling you; the company publishes a false telephone number.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Whether Congress has a lot of work or not, at the end of the day, can you recover those statutory damages?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no, no, no. I'm sorry.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The injury they identify is we don't think companies should public false -- publish false information about you. Is it the end of the standing inquiry to say they published false information about me, or do you have to ask were you injured in some way by that publication?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So it's in -- so Alderson Reporting Company what --  what would you say the injury in fact, not in law but in fact, is in that case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But our cases have always said actual injury in fact. And I thought that meant that that was different than actual injury in law. You're saying when we say injury in fact, we really mean injury in fact or injury in law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, but --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's a very different question. I understand generalized grievance. You can't just say -- even I think you gather -- any citizen in the United States can sue about this. You have to particularize it to some extent. But that's a different question as to whether there's actual injury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I would think that's the particularized part.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But how in the Chief Justice's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but the law -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Concrete -- concrete has nothing to do with particularized. It means it is -- it is -- the only way to put it is an injury in fact. It's a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I was going to say, the -- the Lujan case says de facto, which is actual, existing in fact, having effect, even though not formally or legally recognized.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, but this is my own view of this, maybe no one else's. But you sound as if you're describing a forum of what used to be called the "public action," of which there were no such examples in Federal law. Most states have them. And because you want people who aren't hurt in fact to be able to sue. And the example here is not just the Chief Justice's, which is one, but the more immediate example, which seems to be in this case -- I didn't think it was but it now seems to be -- are people -- perhaps not this plaintiff -- but people who in fact notice that someone like the defendant has filed bad Alderson Reporting Company procedures leading to false information. And those people who were not injured bring a lawsuit, and they say they're following bad information. That's it. Bad procedure. And Congress gave me a hundred dollars, so give it to me. Now, that's the person I didn't know was in this case, because this plaintiff seems to argue specific discrepancies in fact that, in all likelihood, hurt him. Okay? But we're leaving him out of it. Now, I want to know what the government thinks of the case I've just put. Do -- does the government think a person who admits nobody said anything wrong about me, they did say something about me, it was all correct, but they are using bad, bad in -- practices for assembling consumer information -- In the government's view, does the person in my hypothetical, similar to the Chief's, maybe identical, does he or does he not have standing? Yes or no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine. If you say he does not, then we are limiting this case to the case of people who are victims of not just bad practices but Alderson Reporting Company false information about them, and that's what the words "with respect to any consumer" mean.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They mean any consumer who has obtained --  who suffers from false information.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If that's the government's position, then it's not a public action. It's a private action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: That's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: In relation to that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: --  that --  that's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Could I just say --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Justice Alito.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: In relation to that, can I just ask you something about that, that goes to how Spokeo operates: Is there anything here to indicate that anybody other than Mr. Robins ever did a search for him? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Then how could --  then isn't Alderson Reporting Company that quintessential speculative harm? In my understanding -- you -- correct me if I'm wrong -- you don't have files someplace for every person in the United States or -- you have databases, and you will do a search if somebody asks you to do a search. I assume you wouldn't say that somebody as to whom there never had been a search would have standing, right? Even if -- you know, even if it would be the case that if there was a search it would come up with a lot of false information.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I thought they had some -- I thought they had some disclaimer that Spokeo does not verify or evaluate each piece of data, It makes no warranties or guarantees about any of the information offer -- offered.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How is that saying if it's not accurate you're a -- he's a liar?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I think that's what the disclaimer is saying. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You've got to do the best you can, you know? I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I said you've got to do the best you can.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The person who hires somebody, if --  if they all have this disclaimer, which I expect they all do, you --  you either go without any information or you accept one of them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I want to ask about what you think Congress did. You're --  you're saying it's limited to -- to people about whom false information has been given. Suppose Congress enacts a statute that says everybody has a right to sue for exorbitant expenditures by the Alderson Reporting Company Department of Defense. This affects everybody, you know, the $900 toilet seat and so forth. Everybody can sue. That clearly would not be allowable. But suppose somebody is a --  a disappointed bidder for the toilet seat, and he sues under that statute. And he said, oh, yes, the statute didn't -- didn't just say the disappointed bidders can sue, or that anybody who's proximally affected can sue. It said that everybody can sue. But I, in fact, have been proximally injured, and therefore, I ought to be able to sue. Do you think that would be true?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, why is this case any different? You're --  you're saying only people who have been injured, assuming that --  that false information is injury --  only they can sue. But the statute doesn't say that only they can sue. It says that everybody about whom Spokeo did --  did a report can sue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's fine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where do you get the -- the necessity of injury in fact?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where do you get the necessity that there has been false information which you assert is there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Procedures to ensure maximum. That doesn't mean there has to be accuracy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You have to say, don't you, in answer to Justice Scalia, that the words, "follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy in respect to any consumer," the one who can sue, means that the --  when you fail to do it in respect to a consumer, you say something false about that consumer. It doesn't use those words, and we would have to so construe it in order to save the constitutionality of the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that wouldn't be true. You could fail to --  to follow the procedures and still come up with accurate information, like you could not have an number.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's impossible to read it that way because it's simply not true.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But I want to -- as I understand -- I take the falsity out of the -- the hypotheticals to get exactly what your position is on the -- the breadth of Congress' power. So let's say the statute says anybody who's publishing information about you has to pay the individual $10 a year. They think that's a good way to regulate it. It's information about you, good, bad, or indifferent, pay them $10 a year, no more, no less. Spokeo, or whatever that business is, pays you $20 one year. Now you've been -- the statute has been violated with respect to you, a particular individual. Can that -- and there's statutory damages of $10,000. Can that individual sue?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Now, does that individual have injury in fact because the statute has been violated with respect to him?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, no, no, no. You have to have published information about an individual. Every individual who you publish information about gets $10 a year.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So there'd be no standing -- that person would have no standing, even though Congress gave him standing?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So if the statute --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- says $10, no more, no less, he gets $20, does he have standing to sue under that statute?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no, no. Any -- Alderson Reporting Company you have --  I said this just before. They have to have published information about you. If they don't, they don't have to pay you anything.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Isn't there always a materiality question? In every violation there's always a materiality question: What is the falsehood? Is it material to anything? It could be a transposition of a telephone number.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Consovoy, can I just make sure I understand? You said you --  you need for the information to be inaccurate to have standing here. That is going to mean that the class, as you've defined it, is not going to be certified. And I think that that's the right answer, but I just want to make sure that we're on the --  we're on the same page here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And one very quick thing. You said in your brief you're really only suing under 1681(e)(B).

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Can I understand that to be Alderson Reporting Company that you're waiving all claims of other things?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are you saying --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are you saying you get the statutory damages for the four claims that you listed, or is it only what you've called the overarching claim? And in one footnote you said these other claims are -- are just supportive of the main claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So are you asking for four times the statutory damages, or are you saying, no, this is really one -- one claim, and so we're asking for $100 dollars a head, or 10,000 -- or for $1000 a head?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's one claim.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The Ninth Circuit didn't address that question, did it? I mean, as I understand it, I'm looking at the footnote, you know, on page 9A, it says it doesn't matter because you -- the statutory injury in law is enough.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. How does it follow from the common law of defamation? I mean, you -- you could not bring a defamation action because Alderson Reporting Company somebody said something false about you. It was either in one of those areas where it is presumed to be damaging, you know, such as it's, you know, about your moral life or something like that, or --  or your incompetence in your profession, or else you had to show positive damage. How can you say --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: --  that it's from common law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, I see. Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Close enough. Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Stewart.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What --  what happened to "concrete and particularized"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We --  we say that in -- in --  in, gee, a whole lot of cases. And --  and that didn't appear in that quote you gave?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Say it again.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Stewart, let's say your -- your -- Congress thinks that the president is not doing enough to stop illegal immigration. So it passes a law that says, anyone in a border state -- so it's particularized -- who is unemployed may bring an action against an illegal immigrant who has a job. And they get damages, maybe they get an injunction. Can Congress do that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I think that's kind of avoiding the hypothetical. I mean, let's -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But presumably you would raise those issues after the action's been filed, Alderson Reporting Company and --  and, you know, you could raise those issues as an amicus defending the action.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, we're talking about Congress says, Well, these people who are unemployed, illegal immigrants have jobs, they should be able to sue to stop that because the --  you know, because they --  Congress thinks the president isn't doing enough.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I mean, you know the -- you know the objection behind -- behind my hypothetical.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Which is Congress can say, basically, to a group of citizens, you get to enforce one of our laws because we're giving you a cause of action. It doesn't matter whether you've actually been injured or not; we just have to particularize it to some extent. And I would have thought that the -- the president would be concerned about Congress being able to create its own enforcement mechanism. I thought that you would be concerned that that would interfere with the executive's prerogatives.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The statute we're dealing Alderson Reporting Company with here treats everybody about whom false information has been given as somebody about whom false information that harms him has been given. I mean, the class is not -- is not coextensive with those -- those that are harmed. And it's the same -- it's the same in -- in the Chief Justice's hypothetical: The class is not coextensive with everybody who has been -- who has been cheated out of a job by a -- by an unlawful immigrant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In the community -- in -- in the border states is not proximate enough for you. Let's just say anybody who is unemployed in the community where there is an illegal immigrant can sue.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How -- how -- the difference is that this is dealing with the requirement of a case or controversy which has always been recognized as at the core of Article III jurisdiction. And we have a legion of cases that say you have to have actual injury. That's what makes it a decision appropriate for resolution by the judicial branch. And it seems a little bit more important than saying you can challenge particular statutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- we've also said that violation of a procedure, even if you are given a right to the procedure, that alone does not suffice for standing. That is a procedure -- that -- that is a procedure in vacuo that leads to nothing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We -- we said that, so it has to be something more than just the violation of what the -- what Congress says is a legal right. That -- that is not enough.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Right -- right here we have in the complaint, I guess, there were certain errors: A photograph of the wrong person; a statement that he's in his 50s; he isn't. That he's married; he isn't. He's employed in a professional or technical field; he isn't. Alderson Reporting Company That he has children; he doesn't. That he has a graduate degree; he doesn't. That his economic health is very strong; it isn't. And his wealth level is in the top percent; it isn't. Okay? So that, I gather, is what he is complaining about. Something like that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine. Now, for purposes of deciding this case, are we simply to refer to this and say, this is a case about a person who's complaining this? And is this, which I just listed, a sufficiently-concrete injury?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Thank you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Was it -- then that's not what the Ninth Circuit based its decision on. The Ninth Circuit says he had standing by virtue of the alleged violations of his statutory rights, without respect to whether there was harm to his employment process or related anxiety. So I would suppose, if we're going to decide it on that basis, we have to determine that the Ninth Circuit's rationale was in -- was wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And -- and Mr. Stewart, if I could just --  I mean, the --  maybe this is the sentence that you're talking about. At one point the Court says, "the interests protected by the statutory rights at issue are sufficiently concrete and particularized." Now, look, it's not a good opinion, and then it doesn't tell you why it is that they're sufficiently concrete. But they clearly held that they were sufficiently concrete. They understood that as part of the test. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Pincus, you have three minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So are we ruling on the outcome or are we ruling on the reasoning?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I think -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: See, I look at this case slightly differently. I think the breach of any legal right you're given is -- gives Article III jurisdiction. There is a difference between that and whether you're within the zone of interest of a statute. And so what you're saying -- I -- I guess that's why the circuits below have said you have to be able to allege some falsity in the credit report to get recovery under the statute because those are the people the statute was targeted to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But here you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We have one brief, the brief of the restitution scholars who say if this Court says that you have to show -- how can -- some harm, what happens to all the restitution cases where you measure the relief by the gain to the defendant? There has been no loss to the plaintiff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So what is -- what is the harm to the neighbor whose -- puts a toe into his Alderson Reporting Company neighbor's land?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
